Award.AwardTitle: SAVI: Climate Change, Human Adaptation and Risks to Sustainable Freshwater Ecosystems in the Western Hemisphere and Beyond

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
1336839
Harmon

This Science Across Virtual Institutes (SAVI) project will integrate multiple sustainability research efforts in the western hemisphere by examining climate-driven risks to freshwater ecosystems and the services they provide. The connection between climate variation and threats to ecosystem services is poorly understood and difficult to assess because it depends on regional climate responses to global climate change. The value of ecosystems services varies locally and regionally with varying human needs and cultural settings. Hence, assessing (and mitigating) these threats to tightly coupled natural-human system requires a multidisciplinary approach addressing scientific, socioeconomic and cultural aspects. In this project, researchers from the U.S. will team with complementary investigators from Canada, Argentina, Colombia, Chile, Uruguay, and future participating nations globally. The goal of this SAVI is to enable all these researchers to expand their geographical and socioeconomic coverage to better assess climate- and human-forced risks to freshwater ecosystems and services, and to develop adaptation strategies. The project will achieve this goal by (1) Developing and implementing a standardized environmental cyberinfrastructure (technology for data acquisition, management, and collaborative analysis) to employ freshwater ecosystems globally as sentinels of climate variability and risk to services (particularly in previously unobserved settings in Central and South America); (2) Investigating watershed and ecosystem interactions with multiple stressors to assess risks to ecosystem services across geophysical, socioeconomic, and cultural gradients; (3) Enhancing international collaboration between the U.S., Canada and Latin American nations in developing transferrable strategies for stakeholder engagement to determine management and mitigation strategies which are both technically and economically feasible, as well as culturally acceptable; and (4) Integrating our graduate student training and subsequent doctoral research to train the next generation of internationally engaged, inter-disciplinary aquatic ecosystems researchers who will attack scientific challenges of importance to society.

Humans benefit from resources and processes supplied by freshwater ecosystems, including streams, rivers, lakes and wetlands. This work will study how these benefits, which are referred to as ecosystem services, are expected to change with changing climate. Ecosystem services can be grouped into four broad categories: provisioning (drinking water or hydropower for example), regulating (such as modulating climate, controlling disease), supporting (such as distributing sediments and nutrients), and cultural (such as recreational benefits). The project will unite engineers, earth scientists, biologists and social scientists in an effort aimed at understanding how quickly and how severely climate changes will affect aquatic ecosystems in different places. At the same time, the investigators will identify suitable strategies for people to reduce the impact of these changes by adapting practices locally or regionally. People living in different places value ecosystems services differently. For example, people living in a large city may value drinking water or the quality of a fishery differently than people living on a lake. Part of this project will focus on identifying successful adaptation strategies within different cultures and socioeconomic settings and communicating these strategies to relevant stakeholders. Lastly, the project will continuously involve undergraduate and graduate students in its research and stakeholder outreach activities in order to better prepare them to address the challenges ahead for our global well-being.

This award is designated as a Science Across Virtual Institutes (SAVI) award and is being co-funded by NSF?s Office of International and Integrative Activities.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This Science across Virtual Institutes (SAVI) project examined the problem of how changing climate and activities like farming and fishing are threatening the world’s water bodies and the services they provide to people. It did so by (1) linking investigators from several larger research projects focused on these problems in specific regions of the world, and (2). What differentiates the SAVI project from similar research is that it focuses on understanding similarities and differences between how these problems play out in different nations, where climate, governance, economies and cultures are different.  The major outcomes of this project were two-fold. First, we identified and tested a clear strategy for quantifying and comparing risks to water services across a wide range of climatic, socio-economic and cultural conditions. Second, we expanded the U.S. capacity to engage in studies on international environmental issues. More specific achievements related to these SAVI project outcomes include the following:

  1. International collaboration by investigators and students. International collaborative working groups were organized and these led to several new tools and ways of thinking. First, a new tool for ranking threats to water bodies and the services they provide people using readily available water supply, socio-economics, and governance-related information. Second, we learned how to incorporate ancient (“paleo”) environmental information into this problem, and learned that one can better understand future problems by examining the magnitude of the problems under different climate conditions in the past. Third, we found that engaging with stakeholders when defining the problems and identifying possible solutions is critical, and that stakeholders in different socio-cultural settings need to be engaged differently. Lastly, the working groups developed and tested a watershed simulation technique for examining how climate affects water and nutrients in different settings.
  2. Broadening U.S. participation in human-environmental systems research in Latin America. SAVI funds were distributed to U.S. participants to enable them to attend meetings and contribute to research in Latin America. Specifically, investigators from Bard College, UCLA, and the Carey Freshwater Institute were supported to help synthesize stakeholder engagement activities for multiple international sites. Investigators from the University of Nevada Reno were supported to help create an integrated watershed modeling approach aimed at characterizing the transport and fate of carbon in the watershed in response to climatic and land use changes. 
  3. Graduate Student and Early Career Investigator Training. SAVI project participants from Bard College, UCLA, University of Vermont, University of Nevada Reno, and the Carey Freshwater Institute provided planning and instructional time for graduate student and early career investigator workshops held at Latin American sites. The main workshops topics were (1) watershed modeling (15 participants), (2) watershed stakeholder engagement (40 participants), and (3) team science best practices (40 participants). In addition, several graduate student exchanges took place in order to cross-train these students, including moving Argentine students to U.S. labs (2 times) and moving one Chilean student to a U.S. lab, one Argentinean student to a Canadian lab, and one Mexican student to a U.S. lab.
  4. Stakeholder engagement and educational outreach. SAVI participants helped develop site-specific stakeholder engagement plans and surveys across a variety communities associated with study sites in Canada, the U.S., and Latin American. To inspire the next generation of stakeholders and environmental problem-solvers, we edited a children’s book in English and Spanish (The Pink Brush/El Cepillo Rosado). To date, we have disseminated over 1000 copies of our children's book in the U.S., Central and South America, Europe, Africa, Asia, and Australia. The book was adopted for use in the middle school English language program in a rural Argentine school district in the Buenos Aires province. SAVI-supported participants also collected and synthesized data and information on stakeholder characteristics and interactions from all of the SAFER sites.
